Education

Understanding Coffee Origins: Why Terroir Matters

2025-02-10 · 6 min read · Marcus Webb

Where your coffee grows shapes everything in the cup. Here’s why origin matters.

Terroir Altitude, soil, rainfall, and temperature affect how coffee develops. High-altitude beans often have more acidity and complexity; lower elevations can be rounder and sweeter. Soil and climate vary by region—so Yirgacheffe tastes different from Huila.

Processing After harvest, coffee is processed: washed (fermented, then washed), natural (dried in the fruit), or honey (some fruit left on). Washed coffees tend to be cleaner and brighter; naturals can be fruitier and heavier.

Why we list origin At EMBER we put the country and region on every bag. We want you to know exactly where your coffee came from and to connect the flavor in the cup to the place it was grown. That’s part of craft and sustainability.
